content: PRACTICE GUIDELINE FOR THE Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition. This practice guideline was approved in December 2005 and published in June 2006 by the American Psychiatric Association (APA).
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: This practice guideline was developed under the auspices of the Steering Committee on Practice Guidelines by the Work Group on Psychiatric Evaluation, with contributions from various committees, liaisons, and staff from the American Psychiatric Association. The development process represents a synthesis of current scientific knowledge and rational clinical practice on the psychiatric evaluation of adults, striving to be free of bias.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: The APA Practice Guidelines are not intended to be construed or to serve as a standard of medical care. Standards of medical care are determined on the basis of all clinical data available for an individual patient and are subject to change as scientific knowledge and technology advance. The ultimate judgment regarding a particular clinical procedure or treatment plan must be made by the psychiatrist in light of the clinical data presented by the patient.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: To minimize bias, mechanisms are in place such as selecting work group members for their expertise and integrity, requiring disclosure of potential conflicts of interest, and conducting iterative reviews by multiple experts, allied organizations, and APA members. The development of APA practice guidelines is not financially supported by any commercial organization.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: The development process for this guideline included a comprehensive literature review using MEDLINE (PubMed) for the period 1994-2005, initial drafting by a work group with clinical and research expertise, and multiple revised drafts with widespread review from 14 organizations and 64 individuals. The guideline is intended to be a synthesis of current scientific knowledge and rational clinical practice.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: This guideline is intended primarily for general, emergency, and consultation evaluations for clinical purposes with adult patients (age 18 or older). Other types like forensic or child custody evaluations are not the focus, but general recommendations may apply. It presumes familiarity with basic principles of psychiatric diagnosis and treatment planning.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: Recommendations are intended to be consistent with the Institute of Medicine report 'Crossing the Quality Chasm,' emphasizing ongoing management of chronic conditions. The initial psychiatric evaluation sets the stage for ongoing care by establishing treatment goals, gathering baseline data, and planning for systematic follow-up.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: The purpose and conduct of a psychiatric evaluation depend on who requests it, why it is requested, and the expected future role of the psychiatrist. Three types of clinical psychiatric evaluations are discussed: 1) general psychiatric evaluation, 2) emergency evaluation, and 3) clinical consultation. At times, establishing an effective working relationship with the patient may take precedence over the comprehensiveness of the initial interview.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: A general psychiatric evaluation's aims are: 1) establish if a mental disorder is present; 2) collect data for differential diagnosis and clinical formulation; 3) collaborate with the patient on an initial treatment plan, focusing on safety and adherence; and 4) identify longer-term issues for follow-up care. It may be necessary to obtain history from collateral sources like family, and while confidentiality is key, it may be attenuated to the extent needed to ensure the safety of the patient or others.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: The emergency psychiatric evaluation occurs in response to thoughts, feelings, or behaviors that are intolerable to the patient or prompt urgent action by others (e.g., violence, self-injury, threats). The aims include: 1) Assess and enhance safety. 2) Establish a provisional diagnosis. 3) Identify family or other involved persons for collateral information. 4) Identify current treatment providers. 5) Identify relevant social, environmental, and cultural factors. 6) Determine if the patient can form an alliance and if involuntary treatment is needed. 7) Develop a specific plan for follow-up and disposition.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: Patients in an emergency psychiatric evaluation have a high prevalence of combined general medical and psychiatric illness, recent trauma, substance use, and cognitive impairment. Therefore, the psychiatrist may need to request or initiate further general medical evaluation to address diagnostic concerns that emerge from the psychiatric evaluation, as initial medical screenings are often limited in scope.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: A clinical consultation is an evaluation requested by other physicians or health care professionals to assist in the diagnosis, treatment, or management of a patient. The aim is to provide clear and specific answers to the questions posed by the referring party. The patient should be informed that the purpose is to advise the party who requested it. Permission to report findings to others needs to be clarified.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: Other psychiatric consultations, such as for legal or administrative purposes (e.g., forensic, disability), are beyond the scope of this guideline. However, general principles apply: 1) the evaluee is usually not the psychiatrist's patient and confidentiality limits should be clarified upfront; 2) legal representation issues should be resolved beforehand; and 3) such consultations often rely heavily on documentary evidence from collateral sources.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: Inpatient settings provide a highly structured environment for intensive observation and ensuring patient safety. This setting facilitates assessment of complex presentations, co-occurring medical conditions, and helps in determining a patient's ability to function in a less restrictive setting. The inpatient evaluation should include, from the outset, an assessment of the patient's access to appropriate treatment following hospitalization (discharge planning).
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: II. Site of the Clinical Evaluation

content: Outpatient settings (e.g., office-based practices, community mental health centers) differ from inpatient settings due to less frequent interviews and less immediate availability of labs and consultants. The psychiatrist has less opportunity to directly observe behavior, making it important to continually reassess if the patient requires a higher level of care. Advantages include greater patient autonomy and a more longitudinal perspective.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: II. Site of the Clinical Evaluation

content: In general medical settings (e.g., hospital emergency departments, medical-surgical units), psychiatric evaluations allow for some direct behavioral observation but less than on psychiatric units. Interviews can be compromised by interruptions and lack of privacy. It is critical to interview the patient's relational network if sensorium is unclear. Documentation in general medical charts should be sensitive to confidentiality and confined to information necessary for the medical team.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: II. Site of the Clinical Evaluation

content: General psychiatric evaluations involve a systematic consideration of broad domains. They are generally based on three sources of information: 1) observation and interview of the patient; 2) information from others (collateral sources); and 3) medical records. An awareness that the patient's current mental state can affect their reporting of information is important.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: The Reason for the Evaluation includes the patient's chief complaint, its duration, and their specific goals for the evaluation. It should be elicited in the patient's own words. If the patient did not initiate the evaluation, the reason another party requested it should be noted. This information influences the focus of the examination.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: The History of the Present Illness (HPI) is a chronologically organized history of current symptoms, including worries, mood changes, suspicions, delusions, hallucinations, and changes in sleep, appetite, libido, concentration, or behavior. It includes symptom severity, time course, and factors the patient believes are precipitating, aggravating, or modifying the illness.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation
metadata.subsection: B. History of the Present Illness

content: The Past Psychiatric History includes a chronological summary of all past episodes of mental illness, treatments, and responses. For somatic therapies (medications, ECT), details on dose, efficacy, side effects, and duration are important. For psychotherapy, details on type, frequency, duration, and the patient's perception of the alliance are key. Past hospitalizations and suicide attempts must be recorded.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: The History of Substance Use includes past and present use of licit and illicit substances (e.g., alcohol, caffeine, nicotine, marijuana, cocaine, opiates). Information should include quantity, frequency, route of administration, pattern of use, functional consequences, tolerance, and withdrawal. Obtaining an accurate history often requires a gradual, nonconfrontational approach and corroboration from family is useful.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: The General Medical History includes known medical illnesses, hospitalizations, procedures, treatments, medications, allergies, and undiagnosed health problems. It is particularly important to inquire about high-prevalence diseases for the patient's demographic and conditions like HIV, neurological disorders, and sleep apnea. Information on all current medications, including over-the-counter, herbal, and alternative treatments, is essential.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: The Developmental, Psychosocial, and Sociocultural History reviews life stages, education, major life events, trauma (physical, emotional, or sexual abuse), and adaptive skills. It includes the patient's capacity for relationships, sexual history, marital history, and parenting. Psychosocial stressors (housing, economic status) and sociocultural supports (family, religion, community) are assessed.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation
metadata.subsection: F. Developmental, Psychosocial, and Sociocultural History

content: The Occupational and Military History describes the sequence of jobs, reasons for changes, quality of work relationships, and work skills. It notes exposure to hazardous materials or unusual stress. For military history, it includes volunteer/draftee status, combat exposure, awards, and discharge status. Experience with workers' compensation or disability is also determined.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: The Legal History includes a description of past or current involvement with the legal system, such as arrests, detentions, jail or prison time, probation, or parole. Interactions with the court system like family court, workers' compensation, or court-ordered treatment are also relevant and may be significant stressors.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: The Family History includes information about the patient's family constellation, quality of relationships, and the general medical and psychiatric health of close relatives (parents, siblings, children). A history of psychiatric hospitalizations, suicide, and heritable disorders (mood disorders, psychosis, substance use disorders) in first- and second-degree relatives is important. A genogram can be helpful.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: The Review of Systems includes current symptoms not already identified in the history of the present illness. This covers vegetative symptoms (sleep, appetite, eating patterns), pain, neurological symptoms, and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue. Special attention is given to typical side effects of medications the patient is receiving.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: A physical examination is necessary to evaluate the patient's general medical status. It may be performed by the psychiatrist or another clinician. Elements include general appearance, vital signs, head and neck, heart, lungs, abdomen, extremities, neurological status, and skin (looking for stigmata of trauma or drug use). In most cases, the physical exam should be chaperoned.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: The Mental Status Examination (MSE) is a systematic collection of data based on observation of the patient's behavior to obtain evidence of symptoms and signs of mental disorders. Its purpose is also to assess insight, judgment, and capacity for abstract reasoning.
source: Practice Guideline for the psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: MSE Component: Appearance and general behavior. In describing the patient's appearance, factors such as approximate age, body habitus, dress, grooming, hygiene, and distinguishing features (e.g., scars, tattoos) may be noted. The patient's general behavior, level of distress, degree of eye contact, and attitude toward the interviewer are also considered.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation
metadata.subsection: L. Mental Status Examination - Appearance and General Behavior

content: MSE Component: Motor activity. The patient's level of psychomotor activity is noted (e.g., agitated, retarded), as is the presence of any gait abnormalities or purposeless, repetitive, or unusual postures or movements (e.g., tremors, dyskinesias, akathisia, mannerisms, tics, stereotypies, catatonic posturing).
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation
metadata.subsection: L. Mental Status Examination - Motor Activity

content: MSE Component: Speech. Characteristics of the patient's speech are described and may include consideration of rate (e.g. pressured, slowed), rhythm, volume, amount, accent, inflection, fluency, and articulation.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: MSE Component: Mood and affect. Mood is the patient's internal, subjective, sustained emotional state. Affect is the patient's externally observable, more changeable emotional state. Affect is described in terms of its range, intensity, stability, appropriateness, and congruence with thought content.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation
metadata.subsection: L. Mental Status Examination - Mood and Affect

content: MSE Component: Thought processes. This describes the flow and association of ideas. It includes descriptions such as coherence, circumstantiality, tangentiality, neologisms, perseveration, flight of ideas, or loose associations.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation
metadata.subsection: L. Mental Status Examination - Thought Processes

content: MSE Component: Thought content. This assesses the substance of the patient's thoughts, including delusions, ideas of reference, overvalued ideas, ruminations, obsessions, compulsions, and phobias. Assessment of suicidal, homicidal, aggressive, or self-injurious thoughts, feelings, or impulses is essential for determining risk.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation
metadata.subsection: L. Mental Status Examination - Thought Content

content: MSE Component: Perceptual disturbances. This includes hallucinations (a perception in the absence of a stimulus) and illusions (an erroneous perception in the presence of a stimulus). These can occur in any sensory modality (auditory, visual, tactile, olfactory, gustatory). Other disturbances include depersonalization and derealization.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation
metadata.subsection: L. Mental Status Examination - Perceptual Disturbances

content: MSE Component: Sensorium and cognition. This is a systematic assessment of cognitive functions. It includes level of consciousness, orientation (person, place, time, situation), attention and concentration, memory (registration, short-term, long-term), fund of knowledge, intelligence, language, drawing, abstract reasoning, and executive functions.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation
metadata.subsection: L. Mental Status Examination - Sensorium and Cognition

content: MSE Component: Insight. This assesses the patient's awareness of their problems and implications. Patients may or may not recognize that their symptoms reflect an illness or that their behavior affects others. It also involves motivation to change, which can be described in 'stages of change' (precontemplation, contemplation, preparation, action, maintenance).
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: MSE Component: Judgment. This assesses the patient's decision-making in their own self-care, interactions, and other recent behavior. It is more helpful to learn about the patient's actual responses and decisions in their life than to ask hypothetical questions (e.g., 'what would you do if you smelled smoke in a theater?').
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.section: III. Domains of the Clinical Evaluation

content: The patient interview is the psychiatrist's primary assessment tool. The most comprehensive information emerges from a combination of 1) open-ended questioning with empathic listening and 2) structured inquiry about specific events and symptoms. Patient satisfaction is greatest when the psychiatrist provides feedback at multiple points during the interview.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: A. Methods of Obtaining Information - 1. Patient Interview

content: When interviewing agitated or aggressive individuals, the psychiatrist must consider their own safety. A safe environment includes having backup personnel available, choosing an appropriate space with access to a door, and avoiding potentially dangerous objects or clothing. A nonconfrontational, straightforward approach is often most effective, focusing on affect management and allowing the patient to ventilate feelings.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: A. Methods of Obtaining Information - 1b. Interviews with agitated or aggressive individuals

content: When using interpreters, professionally trained interpreters with mental health experience should be used. Family members or friends should not be used unless in an emergency or if the patient refuses a professional. The interpreter should be instructed to translate the patient's own words and avoid paraphrasing, except to translate the correct meaning of idioms.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: A. Methods of Obtaining Information - 1a. Use of interpreters in the interview

content: Collateral sources (family members, other important people, records of prior treatment) are frequently useful. This information is particularly important when patients have impaired insight (e.g., due to psychosis, cognitive impairment, or substance use). Except when immediate safety is paramount, patient confidentiality should be respected. It is permissible to listen to information from others as long as confidential information is not provided to the informant.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: A. Methods of Obtaining Information - 2. Use of collateral sources

content: Structured interviews, rating scales, and questionnaires can be useful tools for diagnostic assessment and evaluating treatment outcome. They can help structure a thorough line of questioning and self-report scales can be valuable in opening communication. However, rating scales should never be used alone to establish a diagnosis or treatment plan; they augment, but do not supplant, clinical judgment.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: A. Methods of Obtaining Information - 3. Use of structured interviews and rating scales

content: Functional assessments measure physical activities of daily living (ADLs: eating, toileting, dressing) and instrumental activities of daily living (IADLs: driving, shopping, managing finances). Such assessments are useful for patients disabled by old age, chronic mental illness, or medical conditions, as they help delineate the combined effects of illnesses on patients' lives and monitor treatment effects.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: A. Methods of Obtaining Information - 3. Functional assessments

content: Diagnostic tests (laboratory, imaging, psychological, neuropsychological) are used to: 1) Detect or rule out a disorder. 2) Determine the safety and dose of treatments. 3) Provide a baseline for monitoring treatment effects. 4) Monitor blood levels of medications. There are no 'routine' tests; ordering should be based on a clear rationale for the individual patient.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: A. Methods of Obtaining Information - 4. Use of diagnostic tests

content: The clinical formulation is an integrative synthesis that aids in understanding the patient as a unique person. It goes beyond the diagnosis and includes phenomenological, neurobiological, psychological, and sociocultural issues. It synthesizes the patient's characteristics, predisposing factors, and current symptomatology to explain the presenting problem and guide treatment.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: B. The Process of Assessment - 1. Clinical formulation

content: The DSM-IV-TR Outline for Cultural Formulation provides a systematic method for incorporating sociocultural issues. It includes: 1) Cultural identity of the individual. 2) Cultural explanations of the illness. 3) Cultural factors related to psychosocial environment and functioning. 4) Cultural elements of the relationship between the individual and clinician. 5) Overall cultural assessment for diagnosis and care.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: B. The Process of Assessment - 1a. Cultural formulation

content: Risk assessment is a component of the formulation that evaluates the patient's risk of harm to self or others. This includes suicide, homicide, self-injury, aggression, and neglect of self or dependents. It identifies specific risk factors (demographics, past behavior, diagnosis, symptoms) and protective factors to guide interventions that address safety.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: B. The Process of Assessment - 1b. Risk assessment

content: On the basis of the evaluation, a differential diagnosis is developed using the DSM multiaxial system. The DSM classification and criteria are guidelines to be informed by clinical judgment, not applied in a rote fashion. The system helps organize the patient's clinical status, other affecting factors, and level of functioning.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: B. The Process of Assessment - 2. Diagnosis

content: The initial treatment plan addresses the specific diagnoses and needs identified in the evaluation. It determines the appropriate treatment setting and states short- and long-term goals. A comprehensive plan addresses biological, psychological, and sociocultural domains and is ideally the result of collaboration between the patient, psychiatrist, and other team members.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: B. The Process of Assessment - 3. Initial treatment plan

content: Considerations of privacy and confidentiality are integral to any psychiatric encounter. The default position is to maintain confidentiality unless the patient gives consent or to address the safety of the patient or others. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) provides guidelines for the release of information. Psychotherapy notes are given special protection.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: For individuals in treatment for substance use disorders, the confidentiality provisions of 42 CFR Part 2 are generally more strict than HIPAA and supersede its provisions. Information may only be disclosed to medical personnel in a bona fide medical emergency that poses an immediate threat to health.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation ofauts, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: When interacting with third-party payers (insurance companies), it is useful to obtain contemporaneous consent from the patient for releasing information. With valid consent, the psychiatrist may release sufficient information to the reviewer to understand the rationale for treatment, but may also withhold information not directly relevant to the utilization review or preauthorization decision.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: B. Interactions With Third-Party Payers and Their Agents

content: When a patient is admitted, their legal status (voluntary vs. involuntary) should be promptly clarified. The decision to hospitalize a patient involuntarily depends on risk level, insight, and local legal criteria. Psychiatrists should be familiar with their state statutes regarding involuntary hospitalization and the use of advance directives for psychiatric treatment.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: C. Legal and Administrative Issues in Institutions

content: Special Population: Elderly patients and patients with medical conditions. The evaluation may need greater emphasis on general medical history, cognitive examination, and functional assessment due to high rates of comorbidity, polypharmacy, and cognitive impairment. The personal history should cover common late-life issues like loss, residential moves, and new disabilities.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: Special Population: Incarcerated Persons. Evaluation will place additional emphasis on alcohol/substance use history and legal history. Psychosocial stressors unique to the correctional setting (e.g., denial of parole, assault) are important to assess as they may increase suicide risk. Access to a private and safe space for evaluation is necessary.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: Special Population: Homeless persons. Evaluation may require modifications, as mistrust and a disengaged lifestyle can make a direct approach difficult. The first step is engagement, which can take time and occur in nonclinical settings. The full evaluation often unfolds over numerous, brief, and seemingly casual interactions.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

content: Special Population: Persons with mental retardation (intellectual disability). Obtaining a comprehensive history from family/caretakers is often crucial, as patients may be unable to report on their own mental experiences. Questions must be phrased to be understandable. Evaluation for co-occurring general medical conditions is particularly important due to higher rates of undetected illness and atypical presentations.
source: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition

metadata.title: Practice Guideline for the Psychiatric Evaluation of Adults, Second Edition
metadata.subsection: D. Special Populations - 4. Persons with mental retardation
